content: The Act may be cited as the "Corporate and Criminal Fraud Accountability Act of 2002" and includes criminal penalties for altering documents. The "Corporate and Criminal Fraud Accountability Act of 2002" includes penalties for altering records in federal investigations and bankruptcy, with fines and imprisonment up to 5 years. Additionally, accountants auditing securities issuers must maintain all relevant documents. The Corporate and Criminal Fraud Accountability Act of 2002 mandates that accountants auditing securities issuers must retain all documents related to audits, reviews, or engagements for 5 years. Violating this requirement can result in fines, imprisonment for up to 5 years, or both. This does not exempt individuals from other legal obligations to preserve documents. The Corporate and Criminal Fraud Accountability Act of 2002 imposes criminal penalties for destroying records in Federal investigations, bankruptcy, and corporate audit records. The Corporate and Criminal Fraud Accountability Act of 2002 imposes penalties for securities fraud, including fines and imprisonment for executing schemes to defraud or obtain money through false pretenses in connection with securities. The Corporate and Criminal Fraud Accountability Act of 2002 imposes penalties for securities fraud, including fines and imprisonment up to 10 years. A clerical amendment is made to the table of sections in the United States Code. SEC. 4. Review of federal sentencing guidelines for obstruction of justice and extensive criminal fraud. The United States Sentencing Commission is required to review and amend the Federal Sentencing Guidelines to ensure adequate punishment for obstruction of justice offenses involving destruction or fabrication of evidence, violations of specific sections of the US Code, and fraud offenses with multiple victims. The United States Sentencing Commission must review and amend Federal Sentencing Guidelines to ensure appropriate punishment for obstruction of justice, violations of specific US Code sections, and fraud offenses with multiple victims, especially when the number of victims exceeds 50 and the offense endangers the financial security of victims. SEC. 5. DEBTS NONDISCHARGEABLE IF INCURRED IN VIOLATION OF SECURITIES FRAUD LAWS. Section 523(a) of title 11, United States Code, is amended to include claims related to violation of Federal securities laws or common law fraud. The amendment to Section 523(a) of title 11, United States Code, includes claims related to violation of Federal securities laws or common law fraud, which involve manipulation in connection with the purchase or sale of any security and results from judgments, orders, settlement agreements, or court/administrative orders for damages, penalties, or payments owed by the debtor. SEC. 6. INCREASED PROTECTION OF EMPLOYEES WAGES UNDER CHAPTER 11 PROCEEDINGS. Amends Section 507(a) of title 11, United States Code by increasing the time period to 180 days and the wage limit to $10,000 in paragraphs (3) and (4). SEC. 7. STATUTE OF LIMITATIONS FOR SECURITIES FRAUD. Section 1658 of title 28, United States Code is amended to allow a private right of action for fraud, deceit, manipulation, or violation of securities laws to be brought within 5 years of the violation or 3 years of discovery. This applies to all proceedings covered by this section. The private right of action for fraud, deceit, manipulation, or violation of securities laws can be brought within 5 years of the violation or 3 years of discovery, applying to all proceedings initiated after the enactment of this Act. SEC. 8. Protection for employees of publicly traded companies who provide evidence of fraud. Sec. 1514A of Title 18, US Code, provides whistleblower protection for employees of publicly traded companies, prohibiting any retaliation for reporting conduct believed to be fraudulent. Employees of publicly traded companies are protected under Sec. 1514A of Title 18, US Code, from retaliation for reporting conduct believed to be fraudulent. This includes providing information or assistance to federal agencies, Congress, or supervisors, and participating in legal proceedings. Employees of publicly traded companies are protected under Sec. 1514A of Title 18, US Code, from retaliation for reporting fraudulent conduct by filing a complaint with the Secretary of Labor or bringing a legal action in the appropriate district court. Employees of publicly traded companies are protected under Sec. 1514A of Title 18, US Code, from retaliation for reporting fraudulent conduct. Complaints must be made in accordance with the rules and procedures outlined in section 42121(b) of title 49, United States Code, with specific requirements for notification and legal burdens of proof. Actions must be initiated within 180 days of the violation, and remedies are available for employees who prevail in such actions. An employee prevailing in an action under Sec. 1514A of Title 18, US Code is entitled to reinstatement, 2 times the amount of back pay with interest, and compensation for special damages including litigation costs and attorney fees. Punitive damages may be awarded if protected conduct is found to be violated. If the protected conduct of an employee poses a substantial risk to shareholders or the public, punitive damages may be awarded. Factors considered include the significance of the information provided and the employee's role in advancing investigations or protecting the health and safety of others. The employee's protected conduct may result in discrimination, and the risk to shareholders or the public is considered for punitive damages. The employee retains rights under Federal or State law, and voluntary adjudication is not allowed. No employee can be forced to adjudicate their rights under this section through arbitration. SEC. 9. ESTABLISHMENT OF A RETIREMENT SECURITY FRAUD BUREAU. Part II of title 28, United States Code, is amended by adding CHAPTER 40A--RETIREMENT SECURITY FRAUD BUREAU. The Attorney General will establish a Retirement Security Fraud Bureau as a bureau in the Department of Justice. The Director of the Bureau, appointed by the Attorney General, will advise on pension and securities fraud matters and maintain a government-wide data access service. The Attorney General will establish a Retirement Security Fraud Bureau in the Department of Justice to collect and analyze information on pension and securities fraud, disseminate data to law enforcement agencies, and support criminal investigations. The Attorney General will establish a Retirement Security Fraud Bureau in the Department of Justice to support ongoing criminal pension and securities fraud investigations, determine emerging trends, and provide research and analytical services to financial institutions and law enforcement authorities. The Department of Justice will establish a Retirement Security Fraud Bureau to combat pension and securities fraud, assist law enforcement authorities, and receive necessary appropriations for fiscal years 2003-2006. The Department of Justice will establish a Retirement Security Fraud Bureau to combat pension and securities fraud.
